title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.11.30 | 19-07-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session, we will be discussing from the 30th verse of the 11th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and an introduction to the verse that will be discussed from Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.transcript: Om Agyana Timiraandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chakshurun Meelitangena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha Nama Om Vishnupadaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale Shreemate Bhaktivedanta Swamin Nithinamine Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatyade Shatarine Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shiva Sadhi Gauravakta Vrinda Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam Deviim Saraswatiim Vyasam Tato Jaya Mudhirayet Om Namah Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya

segments.key_quote: The personality of Godhead means one who is full with all power, all energy, all opulences, all beauties, all knowledge, and all renunciation.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the meaning of the verse, focusing on the opulence of Lord Krishna and the description of his palaces, drawing from Srila Prabhupada's purport and defining the term Bhagavan.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing from the 30th verse of the 11th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. Athavishat Swabhavanam Sarvakamam Anuttamam Prasadayatra Patneenam Sahasranicha Shodasha. The meaning of this verse is, "Thereafter, the Lord entered his palaces, which were perfect to the fullest extent. His wives lived in them, and they numbered over 16." So, Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, Lord Krishna had 16,108 wives, and for each and every one of them, there was a fully equipped palace, complete with necessary compounds and gardens. Full description of these palaces is given in the 10th canto. All these palaces were made of the best marble stone. They were illuminated by jewels, and decorated by curtains and carpets of velvet and silk, nicely bedecked and embroidered with gold lace. These things we can't even imagine in our present yuga. The personality of Godhead means one who is full with all power, all energy, all opulences, all beauties, all knowledge, and all renunciation. That's the meaning of the word Bhagavan—full of six opulences. Therefore, in the palaces of the Lord, there was nothing wanting for fulfilling all desires of the Lord. The Lord is unlimited, and therefore his desires are also unlimited. And the supply is also unlimited. Therefore, his desires are also unlimited.

segments.key_quote: When the great sage Narada heard that Lord Krishna had married 16,000 wives after he had killed the demon Narakasura, Narada was astonished.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Narada's visit to Dwarka, describing the city's beauty, the palaces of Krishna's wives, and the overall opulence, based on the 10th canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.transcript: Everything being unlimited, it is concisely described here as sarvakamam sarvakamam anuttamam—sarvakamam, full with all desirable equipment. Now, in the 10th canto, there is a beautiful description of the palaces of Krishna. In the 69th chapter of the 10th canto, there is a description. When the great sage Narada heard that Lord Krishna had married 16,000 wives after he had killed the demon Narakasura, sometimes also called Bhamasura, Narada was astonished. The Lord Krishna had expanded himself into 16,000 forms and married these wives simultaneously in different palaces. So, being inquisitive as to how Krishna was managing his household affairs with so many wives, Narada, desiring to see these pastimes, set out to visit Krishna's different homes. So, when Narada arrived in Dwaraka, he saw gardens, and parks full of various flowers of different colors, and orchards overloaded with a variety of fruits. Beautiful birds were chirping, and peacocks crowed delightfully. There were ponds full of blue and red lotus flowers, and some of these tanks were filled with varieties of vegetables, and varieties of lilies. The lakes were full of nice swans and cranes, and the voices of these birds resounded everywhere. In the city of Dwaraka, there were as many as 900,000 great palaces. How many? Nine lakh palaces, built of first-class marble, with gates and doors made of silver. The pillars of the houses and palaces were bedecked with jewels, such as touchstone, sapphire, emerald, and the floors gave off a beautiful luster. Floor giving off luster. Have you ever heard of this? The highways, lanes, streets, crossings, and marketplaces were all beautifully decorated. The whole city was full of residential homes, and streets and also the thresholds of every residential house were very clean. On both sides of every path there were bushes and at regular intervals there were large trees that shaded the avenues so that the sunshine would not bother the passer-by. In this greatly beautiful city of Dwarka, Lord Krishna the Supreme Personality of Godhead had many residential quarters. The great Kings and Princes of the world used to visit these palaces just to worship Lord Krishna. The architectural plans were made personally by Vishwakarma, the engineer of the demigods. And in the construction of the palaces of Lord Krishna, he exhibited all of his talents and ingenuity. These residential quarters numbered more than 16,000.

segments.key_quote: The great sage Narada entered one of these houses and saw that the pillars were made of coral and the ceilings were bedecked with jewels.
segments.summary: The speaker continues the description of Krishna's palaces, focusing on the intricate details of the architecture, decorations, and the service provided by numerous maidservants and manservants.
segments.transcript: And a different queen of Lord Krishna resided in each of them. As many queens, so many palaces, one for each queen. The great sage Narada entered one of these houses and saw that the pillars were made of coral and the ceilings were bedecked with jewels. The walls as well as the arches between the pillars glowed. The palaces were decorated with decorations made of different kinds of sapphires. Throughout the palace were many canopies made by Vishwakarma that were decorated with strings of pearls. All this is a factual description. This is not somebody's imagination. This is not some mythology, because the Lord is full of all opulences. So what is surprising if his palaces are so beautifully decorated. The chairs and other furniture were made of ivory and bedecked with gold and diamonds, and jewel lamps dissipated the darkness. The material nature by constitution is dark, but when there is a need of a light source, the Lord's palace was illuminated by jeweled lamps—the jewels which emit light. There was so much incense and fragrant gum burning that the scented fumes were coming out of the windows. The peacock sitting on the steps became illusioned by the fumes mistaking them for clouds and began dancing jubilantly. So beautiful. The smoke coming out of the windows seemed like clouds for the peacocks sitting on the windows, and they were dancing very jubilantly. There were many maid servants, thousands and thousands of maid servants in each palace, and all of them were decorated with gold necklaces, golden bangles and beautiful saris. There were also many man servants nicely dressed in cloaks and turbans and jeweled earrings. Beautiful as they were, the servants were all engaged in different household duties.

segments.key_quote: This material world is filled with miseries. It's the nature of this material world. We don't belong here.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the opulence of the spiritual world with the suffering of the material world, emphasizing that Krishna's opulence is meant to attract conditioned souls and that material pleasures are not real.
segments.transcript: So this is just to give us an idea. What is the kind of opulence of the Supreme Lord? You cannot compare it with opulence of the richest person in this entire creation, material creation. Of course, in the spiritual world, the Lord enjoys with all his devotees. He shares his opulences. Nobody there is bereft of any need, necessity. To serve the Lord, they have everything that they simply desire, because there are desire trees in the spiritual world. But even when Krishna appeared on this earth planet, He brought down his opulence. His abode descended. Dwaraka Dham, Mathura Dham, Vrindavan Dham descended with Krishna. And naturally, these beautiful places were full of the opulences. This is just to attract the conditioned soul, to prepare themselves to go to the spiritual world and live with Krishna as one of his associates in a loving relationship. Each one of us is God with Krishna. Krishna wants to attract us. Why are you suffering in this material world? This material world is filled with miseries. It's the nature of this material world. We don't belong here. Foolishly, ignorant people may think that even if there are miseries, let me make adjustment and learn to live, and try to enjoy the pleasures available in this world—the material pleasures available. But Bhagavad Gita says material pleasures are not real pleasures.

segments.key_quote: Krishna invites us. Please come to the spiritual world. And simply by chanting Hare Krishna and perfecting our devotional service, we can immediately transfer ourselves to the spiritual world.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by inviting listeners to seek spiritual bliss with Krishna, highlighting Krishna's availability to all and the power of devotional service, particularly chanting Hare Krishna, to attain the spiritual world.
segments.transcript: They are simply due to some sense contact producing some sensation, and it is wrongly interpreted as material pleasure. But actually it is simply different kind of distress. It is filled with distresses, this material existence, and different kinds of distresses are interpreted. Or if there is a relief from some distress that is thought of as happiness, pleasure, material pleasure. So we are entitled to pure spiritual bliss of the kind that Krishna enjoys with his associates. And in the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna is inviting, "Come. Come to me. Live with me. Enjoy with me." And that too in a loving relationship. Krishna is one. Living entities are countless. But that doesn't mean that Krishna is unavailable for some insignificant living being. No. Krishna is available for each and every living being in the spiritual world. Why spiritual world? Even the material world. He has expanded as Paramatma in the heart of everyone, of each one of us. He is available for each one of us, even in the material world. But material world is not direct. Spiritual world is direct relationship—directly available. So Krishna invites us, "Please come to the spiritual world." And simply by chanting Hare Krishna and perfecting our devotional service, we can immediately transfer ourselves to the spiritual world. I'll stop here. Thank you very much. Hare Krishna.
